title: group
text: Definition 1 (A group is a non-empty set \(\Group\) together with a binary operation on \(\Group\), denoted “\(\GroupOperation\)”, that combines any two elements \(\GroupElement\) and \(\GroupElement'\) of \(\Group\) to form an element of \(\Group\), denoted \(\GroupOperation{\GroupElement,\GroupElement'}\), such that the following three requirements, known as group axioms, are satisfied:)

title: group
text: Definition 1 (A group is a non-empty set \(\Group\) together with a binary operation on \(\Group\), denoted “\(\GroupOperation\)”, that combines any two elements \(\GroupElement\) and \(\GroupElement'\) of \(\Group\) to form an element of \(\Group\), denoted \(\GroupOperation{\GroupElement,\GroupElement'}\), such that the following three requirements, known as group axioms, are satisfied:)

title: axioms
text:
Definition 1 For all \({#1},{#2},{#3}\) in \(\Set\), one has \(\Operation{(\Operation{#1}{#2})}{#3}=\Operation{#1}{(\Operation{#2}{#3})}\).


Definition 2 There exists an element \(\Identity\) in \(\Set\) such that, for every \({#1}\) in \(\Set\), one has \(\Operation{\Identity}{#1}={#1}\) and \(\Operation{#1}{\Identity}={#1}\). Such an element is unique and is called the identity element.


Definition 4  

Definition 3 For each \({#1}\) in \(\Set\), there exists an element \({#2}\) in \(\Set\) such that \(\Operation{#1}{#2}=\Identity\) and \(\Operation{#2}{#1}=\Identity\), where \(\Identity\) is the identity element.

For each \({#1}\), the element \({#2}\) is unique and is called the inverse of \({#2}\) and is denoted \(\Inverse{#1}\).

title: axioms
text:
Definition 1 For all \({#1},{#2},{#3}\) in \(\Set\), one has \(\Operation{(\Operation{#1}{#2})}{#3}=\Operation{#1}{(\Operation{#2}{#3})}\).


Definition 2 There exists an element \(\Identity\) in \(\Set\) such that, for every \({#1}\) in \(\Set\), one has \(\Operation{\Identity}{#1}={#1}\) and \(\Operation{#1}{\Identity}={#1}\). Such an element is unique and is called the identity element.


Definition 4  

Definition 3 For each \({#1}\) in \(\Set\), there exists an element \({#2}\) in \(\Set\) such that \(\Operation{#1}{#2}=\Identity\) and \(\Operation{#2}{#1}=\Identity\), where \(\Identity\) is the identity element.

For each \({#1}\), the element \({#2}\) is unique and is called the inverse of \({#2}\) and is denoted \(\Inverse{#1}\).

title: Følner sequence
text:
Definition 1 We define a right-Følner sequence in \(\Group\) as a sequence \(\Folner=(\Folner_N)_{N\in\mathbb{N}}\) of finite subsets of \(\Gamma\) satisfying \[\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|(\Folner_N\cdot \GroupElement^{-1})\cap\Folner_N|}{|\Folner_N|}=1\]for all \(\GroupElement\in\Group\).


Definition 2 Similarly, we define a left-Følner sequence in \(\Group\) as a sequence \(\Folner=(\Folner_N)_{N\in\mathbb{N}}\) of finite subsets of \(\Gamma\) satisfying \[\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|(\GroupElement^{-1}\cdot\Folner_N)\cap\Folner_N|}{|\Folner_N|}=1 \]for all \(\GroupElement\in\Group\).


Definition 3 We call a sequence a Følner sequence if it is both a left and right Følner sequence.

title: Følner sequence
text:
Definition 1 We define a right-Følner sequence in \(\Group\) as a sequence \(\Folner=(\Folner_N)_{N\in\mathbb{N}}\) of finite subsets of \(\Gamma\) satisfying \[\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|(\Folner_N\cdot \GroupElement^{-1})\cap\Folner_N|}{|\Folner_N|}=1\]for all \(\GroupElement\in\Group\).


Definition 2 Similarly, we define a left-Følner sequence in \(\Group\) as a sequence \(\Folner=(\Folner_N)_{N\in\mathbb{N}}\) of finite subsets of \(\Gamma\) satisfying \[\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|(\GroupElement^{-1}\cdot\Folner_N)\cap\Folner_N|}{|\Folner_N|}=1 \]for all \(\GroupElement\in\Group\).


Definition 3 We call a sequence a Følner sequence if it is both a left and right Følner sequence.
